INTRODUCTION
The City of Dallas Water Utilities maintains a policy of safe water and wastewater treatment plant operation, reducing to the greatest extent possible any hazards associated with the treatment processes, and reducing any subsequent risk to the surrounding community, their employees, and the environment. They cooperate with the surrounding community and local emergency response agencies to promote effective contingency planning in the unlikely event that a process incident occurs.

As part of this policy, Dallas Water Utilities maintains compliance with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency?s (USEPA) regulations for the prevention and mitigation of accidental releases of extremely hazardous substances under section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act.   Facilities covered by the regulations (40 CFR 68) are required to implement a risk management program and submit a description of the program (called a risk management plan, or RMP) to USEPA.  

The Southside Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) falls under this regulation because of the onsite storage and use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The amounts stored for both chemicals exceed the threshold limits specified by the USEPA, thereby making the facility subject to compliance with the regulation.  

Initially, the digester gas (Methane) generated at the Southside WWTP also fell under the regulation, but is no longer covered.  The Chemical Safety Information, Site Security, and Fuels Regulatory Relief Act, enacted on August 5, 1999, excluded flammable substances from coverage under the Risk Management Program when used as fuel (including flaring) or held for sale as fuel at a retail facility.  Digester gas is used as fuel (or flared) at Southside WWTP.

Dallas Water Utilities first submitted a RMP for the Southside WWTP to USEPA in 1999.   RMPs must be updated and resubmitted to USEPA every five (5) years.  The following information summarizes the Southside WWTP 2004 update and resubmission:

REGULATED SUBSTAN

CES
The Southside WWTP uses chlorine as a disinfectant in the wastewater treatment process.  Sulfur dioxide is used at the plant in the dechlorination process to remove residual chlorine from the treated wastewater prior to discharge into the Trinity River.  

1. Chlorine
The Southside WWTP regularly has a maximum storage quantity of 78 tons of chlorine at its facility.  The chlorine is stored in three 30-ton tanks, each filled with a maximum capacity of 26 tons set by administrative controls.  A fourth tank is always kept empty in case an emergency transfer is necessary.  The total amount of chlorine exceeds the threshold limit of 2,500 pounds set by the USEPA.  

Chlorine is delivered to the Southside WWTP by tanker truck and is stored in the three 30-ton tanks, located inside the Chlorine Building.  

The existing chlorine feed facilities at the Southside WWTP consist of the four inside storage tanks, liquid feed piping and miscellaneous valves, two evaporators, gas piping and miscellaneous valves, four chlorinators, and a scrubber system.  A release of chlorine gas could potentially occur at the chlorine storage area or at the chlorine process areas.

2. Sulfur dioxide
The Southside WWTP stores sulfur dioxide in two 25-ton stationary tanks.  As an administrative control, these tanks are only filled with a maximum of 42,000 pounds for a maximum amount of 42 tons of sulfur dioxide stored onsite at one time.  A third tank always remains empty in case an emergency transfer is necessary.  The total amount exceeds the threshold limit of 5,000 pounds set by EPA.

Sulfur dioxide is delivered to the Southside WWTP by a tanker truck and is stored in the tanks located inside the Sulfur Dioxide Building.  

The existing sulfur dioxide facilities at the Southside WWTP consist of the three 25-ton stationary tanks, liquid feed piping and miscellaneous valves, two evaporators, gas piping and miscellaneous valves, and feeders.  A release of sulfur dioxide gas could potentially o

ccur at the sulfur dioxide storage area or at the sulfur dioxide process areas.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
In May 2004, Dallas Water Utilities and Malcolm Pirnie, Inc. reviewed and updated the offsite consequence analyses at Southside WWTP.   Safety information and hazard analysis documentation were reviewed to determine whether the parameters and assumptions used in the 1999 analyses are still valid. The results of this review are documented and are maintained as part of the RMP records.  Any changes resulting from this review are reported in this resubmission.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The accident history for the Southside WWTP was reviewed for the period from June 1999 through June 2004.  During this period of time, no accidental releases of chlorine occurred that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or any environmental impact.

On October 10, 2001, there was an accidental release of sulfur dioxide during delivery.  The chemical hauler off-loaded in excess of the storage tank, which caused his truck to over pressurize and activate the pressure release valve on the delivery truck.  An unknown amount of sulfur dioxide was released, estimated at less than 25 pounds, causing minor injuries to 5 contractor workers.  The injured were sent to a local hospital for observation and found with no significant health problems.  They were reassessed the next day and were released to their regular job duties.

An incident investigation was performed and corrective actions taken and implemented.

PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Dallas Water Utilities maintains a consistent accidental release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at Southside WWTP.  The program consists of seven elements:

1. Safety Information
Dallas Water Utilities has maintained information concerning process chemicals, technology, and equipment as part of their risk

management program at Southside WWTP.  The information is made available to employees and contractors at Southside WWTP who will work in the chlorine and sulfur dioxide process area.  Emergency response planners can also use the information to develop training programs and procedures.

2. Hazard Review
A hazard review of chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes and procedures is conducted at least every five (5) years to evaluate potential causes and consequences of accidental releases.  A chlorine and sulfur dioxide hazard review using the ?What-If? method was conducted by Malcolm Pirnie, Inc. with the assistance of Southside WWTP plant management and staff familiar with the process? operation and maintenance in May, 2004.  The results of this review identified changes in operating, maintenance, and other process safety management procedures that would improve the overall safety of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems. The changes that most effectively help prevent an accidental release have been implemented, or will be in the future.

3. Operating procedures
Dallas Water Utilities have developed and implemented written operating procedures that provide instructions and step for conducting activities associated with the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes at Southside WWTP consistent with the safety information. Southside WWTP operating procedures include startup, shutdown, and emergency operating procedures, and describe how the system should be operated in order to minimize the chances of an accidental release. The procedures also emphasize safety considerations during operation and address hazardous situations that can occur and how to correct them.

4. Training
All Southside WWTP staff currently involved in chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes have been trained in the classroom and/or during on-the-job training in an overview of the processes and in the operating procedures, as is new staff assigned to the processes.  Training includes emphasis on safety an

d health, hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years to ensure Southside WWTP staff understands and adheres to current operating procedures.  

5. Maintenance
Southside WWTP has developed and implemented a preventive and corrective maintenance program to ensure equipment used to process, store, or handle chlorine and sulfur dioxide is functioning properly and installed to minimize the risk of releases.   The program addresses equipment testing, inspection, and preventive maintenance schedules, and documentation of equipment testing, inspection, and preventive and corrective maintenance activities. 

6. Compliance audits
USEPA?s risk management rule requires that Southside WWTP complete a compliance audit for it?s risk management program at least once every 3 years. The primary goals of conducting a compliance audit are to verify compliance with risk management rule requirements and good process safety practices, identify process safety or program deficiencies and develop corrective actions, and increase safety awareness among Southside WWTP staff.

Malcolm Pirnie, Inc., with the assistance of Southside WWTP plant management and staff familiar with the processes operation and maintenance, conducted an audit as part of the RMP update in May, 2004.  The results of this audit, in addition to recommendations made, are documented and are maintained as part of the RMP records. 

7. Incident Investigation
Southside WWTP management investigates each incident that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide. A process to identify the underlying causes of incidents and implement procedures for preventing similar events has been developed. 

An incident investigation team will be established following criteria established in the Southside WWTP risk management program.  As part of the investigation, an incident report will be prepar

ed to recommend system changes (i.e., operational modifications, additional training and competency requirements), to prevent a similar incident from occurring in the future. The incident investigation report and any changes resulting from the report will be reviewed with all staff members who operate and maintain the applicable system.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN
An Emergency Response Plan (ERP) has been developed for Southside WWTP, which provides specific emergency response procedures for accidental releases of chlorine and sulfur dioxide to ensure that emergency response coverage is available 24 hours per day, 7 days per week.  These procedures include leak investigation, operational-level response activities, and communications to coordinate response activities with outside agencies, such as the City of Dallas Fire Department HAZMAT Team, in the event of an emergency. 

In 2004, the Dallas Water Utilities will update and incorporate this ERP and sections of the risk management program into an ?all-hazard? integrated contingency plan (ICP).  The ICP format will minimize duplication in the preparation and use of emergency response and risk management plans for various regulatory requirements and will eliminate confusion for Southside WWTP staff that may have to decide which plan applies to a particular emergency.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
- Connect automatic shutoff wiring for chlorine and sulfur dioxide.

- Install high scale weight alarm on sulfur dioxide tanks.
